channel.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
channel.description: Alright, so this is for those of you who are professional developers/designers/freelancers, or whatever you call yourself. Basically I'm turning 18 here soon, and I'm wanting to do some freelance work to make some extra money during college, or whatever I end up doing after high school. And to also begin getting connected with people in the business, and potential employers and such. From what I've gathered, GitHub and LinkedIn are going to be two of my best friends for getting myself out there, and then oDesk for freelancing, unless there's something better. One question is: I want to start building a portfolio using GitHub, what are some ideas for programs that I could put on GitHub to show off my work? Any language works, doesn't matter. My main goal is to get into game development, professionally or freelancing or whatever, but I'll settle for general software. Don't know if that matters as far as portfolio's and stuff. Getting connections, I was on LinkedIn a while back, but I never used it so I deleted the account until later on when I was ready to actually put effort into it.. I'll stop rambling there, I'll get some feedback then ask more questions, thanks for anybody who tries to guide me.

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

t4:

yeah, having a ‘portfolio’ is fairly worthless.

On the contrary there are plenty of employers, especially those with less formal employment practices, who will be impressed by the initiative you’ve taken.

Small business would be a primary example, and this is doubly so when you’re after your first job in the industry. Never discount a platform for demonstrating what you can offer in terms of skill set.

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“stCky, post:7, topic:549670”]My honest advice would be to get on Twitter and start following local developers/companies/general techies and joining in on dev conversation there, going to meets/workshops locally will also be a very helpful way to network and meet new people. Without a portfolio or experience working with others it would obviously be hard for someone to gauge your skills, so it would be wise to go ahead and start creating any little helpful tools and scripts you can/want. Small tools are fun and easy and having a range of them available and their source would be impressive.

Oh yo, this guy has a port checker, url shortener, server status checker, calculator etc on his website! They aren’t massively complicated to but his interests and range of tools is impressive etc…[/quote]
Thanks for the further guidance.

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

All you need is some big titties and you will be hired

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

yeah, having a ‘portfolio’ is fairly worthless. it’s more of something to talk about when interviewing if you have anything impressive to talk about. companies care about flexibility, ability to learn, and previous work experience.

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @stCky stCky
item.description:
@stCky wrote:

I’ve never used linkedIn or similar and have never had an online portfolio, other than GitHub which I haven’t contributed to publicly.

My first dev job I was head-hunted straight out of my diploma course and since then all my other work opportunities have been via other dev buddy’s I had met through either work or school.

My honest advice would be to get on Twitter and start following local developers/companies/general techies and joining in on dev conversation there, going to meets/workshops locally will also be a very helpful way to network and meet new people. Without a portfolio or experience working with others it would obviously be hard for someone to gauge your skills, so it would be wise to go ahead and start creating any little helpful tools and scripts you can/want. Small tools are fun and easy and having a range of them available and their source would be impressive.

Oh yo, this guy has a port checker, url shortener, server status checker, calculator etc on his website! They aren’t massively complicated to but his interests and range of tools is impressive etc…

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

try doing programming exercises, small utilities, or start a big project you can finish. i would make sure to document whatever you make thoroughly and make sure you have a consistent style.

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

tyb97:

Interesting. Thanks, so what about networking like LinkedIn? Are either of you on it, and does it bring benefit as far as locating employment, or freelancing?

I have it but don’t use it so I can’t say.

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Interesting. Thanks, so what about networking like LinkedIn? Are either of you on it, and does it bring benefit as far as locating employment, or freelancing?

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Whackatre:

dude, it honestly literally doesn’t even matter. just write something you like, or something that is useful to you – frameworks, games, apis, small cli utilities, etc. contribute to existing open source software if you can (disclaimer: i don’t.) you can brag about it on your cv.

This. Employers want to see what kind of things you are interested and what you have worked on regardless of what it is. Every repo you create on GitHub makes you look good because you understand how to use version control (atleast at a basic level) and of course it’s always good to be involved in open-source.

If you want to be really cool, contribute to other open-source projects.

Read full topic

item.title: Few Questions About Professionalism
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

dude, it honestly literally doesn’t even matter. just write something you like, or something that is useful to you – frameworks, games, apis, small cli utilities, etc. contribute to existing open source software if you can (disclaimer: i don’t.) you can brag about it on your cv.

i hear web dev freelancing is decent.

definitely link your github prof page in your portfolio.

Read full topic
